params.text:
Read the paragraph and answer the questions below:

Food Provenance means having knowledge of your food. Knowing how it was raised or grown, how it was produced and how it was transported.

 In the butchery trade, the ideal situation is to rear your own livestock or to have the ability to source locally from farmers. Either way, you have the advantage of having control of the desired quality of the products you sell. This can be achieved by simply choosing your preferred breeds of animal and required finishing weight, or having an input in the way you prefer certain animals to be fed and finished to your liking.

Stocking authentic homemade products is also an example of how food provenance can be achieved. A butcher lucky enough to be able to source locally raised, organic or free range meats has the advantage of coupling these meats with other quality, locally sourced ingredients to produce a range of artisan products for his/her business.

Not only does this attract a new customer base but also allows the retailer receive a higher price for a more superior product.

Being able to produce homemade burgers, sausages and other value added products with these quality meats sets a business apart from it’s competitors. To have such a USP is an advantage for any business. After all, the best advertising of all is word of mouth.

Happy customers will spread the word to family and friends.         

As consumer interest and knowledge in Food Provenance grows, so too does the need to supply the information such as:

  • Place of Origin.
  • Record of Ownership.
  • Authenticity.
  • Story of a Product.
  • Handmade versus Factory Production.  

Advantages of Food Provenance

  • Enables better prices
  • More value in Product
  • Climate conscious methods of production
  • Different individual product (USP).
  • Shorter route to market.  
  • Quality assured
